comments.commentBody: I'm writing from the other "great white ghetto" of the Central Valley of California. Paul writes of a lack of wage increases and sure enough as a member of a labor union we are fighting for a 2.5% wage increase. This is on the heals of 5-6 years of cuts. The coast of California has rebounded from the recession but people in the valley have not seen it. Foreclosures have taken a toll. Unemployment is 13.3% and we fit the description of one of the white house's promise zones.  These include Kentucky and the choctaw nation.  There is no one here from the 1%. And yet politicians here identify with conservative republicans to the extent that the city council, board of supervisors, utility districts, state assemby and senate members, and house representatives are all conservative republicans. There is no benefit to people in the valley except to keep the status quo for a few. And it's sad to see how many people who have so little continually vote for people who do not have their best interests at heart but simply give them a false lifeline of hope that some day there will not be people who are immigrants or of color or of poverty or or lack or priveledge amongst them. And it holds us back.  We are perpetually the last to know prosperity and the first to know recession.

We need more women in the SC. This cas shouldn't even be allowed t proceed. Insurance companies are paying for Viagra, penile implants, penile pumps. Medicare covers all that stuff, too. This is about controlling women - something every religion is really good at doing.
This SC made a huge mistake with Citizens United. I hope they don't do the same with this case.
Looks like a hippy to me.  I'll take, "All in the Family."
You are right.

Clearly the true meaning of this argument here is not that corporations should have religious beliefs, but that the beliefs of superior "better" people (superior because they are owners) are to be imposed on the needs of the rest ( given they are only employees). As an undercurrent, the Court believes clearly that some religions and beliefs are better than others.

I suspect that the so-called Conservative (really revolutionary) wing of the Court might see good in Christian owners, but will certainly have a prejudice against other religions, from Islam all the way to religions of Native Peoples, Hmong, Shinto, and Wicca.
I am sure they pay customs fees in China, pay Chinese agents, and taxes, and the like... in spite of the fact that abortion is practiced in this country.
Great point, Carol. HL has no problem dealing with abortion enforcers in China.

Sarah-

Cleetus is not paranoid; in fact, he makes a very valid point. The current administration, and its liberal supporters, insist upon using the term “freedom of worship” instead of “freedom of religion”— a dangerous shift of phraseology.

Freedom of worship means you can live out your faith behind the walls of your church. There are lots of countries where you can be executed for being public with your faith or for making a convert, but you have “freedom of worship.”

Freedom of religion implies far more than that. Freedom of religion means that people of faith have the right to let their religious beliefs form everything they do: from politics, to how they express themselves in the public square, to how they do business.

Separation of church and state doesn't mean religion has no place in the public square. It means the government has no place in our religion, and we can bring it anywhere we want and let it inform every decision we make, even the kind of health care we buy for our employees.

The principle is simple, and it is abject how the Court is destroying the intellectual and legal capital it accumulated to gain both authority and authenticity.

A human person can practice their religion without interference, as long as it does not impinge on the rights of others --in this way, others too might practice their religions.

So Hobby Lobby's owners, as persons, can treat or not treat their bodies as they please --but must provide insurance packages and comply with laws enacted by the State. The individual is thus truly respected by the State --the owners individual rights are defended, but so are the individual rights of employees --it is called equality under the Law.

Justice Kagan said, "Your understanding of this law [the Religious Freedom Restoration Act], your interpretation of it, would essentially subject the entire U.S. Code to the highest test in constitutional law". However, She is incorrect; it is the text of that law which explicitly subjects the entire federal law to this standard.
No laws respecting tenets of religion are constitutional in the US, according to the plain meaning of "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion".

This should be the Court's opinion:

Hobby Lobby claims a corporate right to discriminate against women based on its religious beliefs. The government says corporations don't have religious beliefs because they are things, not people, and they can't violate women's due process rights and civil rights. We rule for the government because, well, duh?

AHA! John, me boy, ONEWOOD think you just hit the tribekta, albeit loosely speaking.

IMSAD to say that TBOQ is in dire JEOPARDY of having once again overSTAID his welcome...:-(

Obama is projecting his own liberal values that confuse feelings, appearance, words, and emotion, with real action and content, on uber-old school Russia.

Look around the pictures of the Russian parliament and you will see a room full of the endangered species once referred to as "men." Large, hairy, with ill fitted suits, and nothing metrosexual about them they don't look like the type that would give a darn about teacher Obama's lectures that bullies really are just showing their weakness and lack of self esteem. They just got a whole country without a shot.

In fact bullies do not lack self esteem and are not projecting weakness:

"Contrary to popular belief, bullies are not inwardly anxious, insecure children with a desperate need to boost themselves up by making others afraid of them. Rather, when tested, bullies tend to score high in self-esteem."

http://www.nytimes.com/1996/03/27/us/personal-health-bullying-who-picks-...?

Obama's weak, passive, feeling based analysis of Russian bullying is symptomatic of the general metrosexualazation of modern US society on every level, using ever more far fetched projection and wishful thinking to justify a fear of action, assertiveness, and inability to deal with aggression.

They have Crimea, but we are going to get an A+ on self esteem on out report card - pathetic.

Suppose you run a business. You make cars. You cut lawns. Are you going to hire more people, build more factories, or buy another mower, if you can't sell more cars or cut more lawns? It's true that people want a new car or their lawn cut, but they don't have enough money to pay for the car or the lawn service. Too many are out of work. Too many have low paying jobs.

It's not taxes or regulations that are holding the economy back. It is the lack of money on the part of those who would like to spend it. There are only two sources of money.

1. The Rich have a lot of money. They could afford to pay their workers more, build new factories, hire more people, BUT they are not going to do that until there are people who can buy more stuff.

2. The only other option is the federal government. It can print money. It can spend money. There are many worthwhile ways to do so. It can fix our roads and bridges, build a new power grid, give grants to the states to help with education, sponsor research, etc., etc., etc. Even simply giving money to poor people to buy food gets more money into the economy.

As a percentage of GDP our public debt is about 40% less than it was in 1946. From 1946 to 1973 we increased the debt in dollars by 75%. BUT we had prosperity. Real median household income surged 74%.

After WWI we had 10 years of balanced budget. We decreased the debt in dollars by 40%. This was followed by the worst economy in our history.

Those who don't learn from history are ...

@HBG- your outrageous trope gets tiring as well. As I linked to you last time which I'm sure you refused to check, there were 2 green energy failures, not 34 as you claim. My son is employed by a solar energy company in MA, hardly a warm sunshiny state. In the 1 1/2 years since his employment they have gone from a fleet of 20 trucks to 60, outgrown their present location and have been hiring pretty much nonstop since he started employment there. A typical workweek unless weather conditions are unsafe is 50 hours.
"Solar-energy installations in our nation set a new record last year, giving us the second-strongest solar market in the entire world."
The auto bailout was initiated by Pres. Bush, the wars were started by Pres. Bush. Obama withdrew troops from Iraq and is withdrawing troops from Afghanistan. And more tiring that Obama gave 1.5 billion to the Muslim Brotherhood- "that the $1.5 billion was just the same package of military and economic aid that the U.S. has given to Egypt since 1979, after the Sadat peace accord with Israel." Those pesky facts are so tiring.
Whenever you turn on the news, unless it's FOX, they are discussing yet another oil spill, coal ash spill, tanker explosion, etc. How much pollution and environmental damage is acceptable to you?
The Patriot Bill is included in NDAA funding which funds our military. If you're so concerned with the Patriot Act why not write congress to repeal it? Oh, that's right, almost 100% of Repubs. support it, 210 in fact.

Zoot Rollo: The President is not a dictator; he can't succeed as a leader if his proposals aren't implemented. In the meantime he's deported more illegals than any of his predecessors (look it up!) and the net influx of illegal immigration is now down to zero.
Richard: The healthcare site is now functioning efficiently. The President obviously erred in his statement about getting to keep your current (and crappy) policy but millions of people have been helped by the Affordable Care Act and we're no longer hearing about the "millions" who were hurt by it.
Eric: Your "solution" amounts to Dubya Redux. How do you suppose we got into this mess? Insofar as shrinking bloated government is concerned, please do let us know which programs you're willing to cut or wholly sacrifice among the ones that benefit you, your children or your parents.
HealedbyGod: Sorry: I don't respond to hyperbolic (your word) screeds composed by people who hide behind handles in lieu of commenting under their actual names. In any case, Sharon's response is more than sufficient.

The President and his party have been losing support because the economy's not doing well.  But whose fault is that when the opposition (comprising a majority in one house of Congress and an obstruction-imposing minority in the other) refuses to endorse any one of the President's proposals?  Let's face facts: nothing will change even if the Republicans gain control of the senate.  The GOP won't have the votes to override a presidential veto but the American public will get a clear vision of what they would do if a Republican were elected to the White House in 2016.  Nothing could more effectively usher in the next Clinton administration.
Pets are routinely euthanized when the people who love them decide that it no longer is cost effective to treat them. Do you want that for yourself too?

Recent conversation with a friend who has five rescue pups.  'Jazzy, who was abandoned and whom I rescued from a hurricane, has food issues and attacked Scootie who went over to share her dinner bowl the other night.  He got badly torn up and it cost $700 at the Vet after the damage was repaired and multitude stitches'.  'What!  You must be joking.  Your monthly health insurance coverage is less than $500 now', I replied, 'try looking into some pet insurance too'.  Amazing.

On the other hand, vets have to charge realistically, because the pet owner can, and sometimes does, shrug and say, 'heck, I can get another cat or dog. Let it die'. I use two excellent veterinary hospitals, where we've been going with various companion animals for nearly 40 years. If you've left an animal for overnight treatment, they will not quote prices over the phone. You have to be present for the bill, because people will dorp off a critter, then just not pick up their pet if they decide that they can either pay $500 to get back their healthy Labradoodle, or go to the shelter and pay a $25 adoption fee for a slightly used Labradoodle. For the vet, if you count the cost of your time per hour, even going to small claims court isn't worth it. (And you still have to do something with the poor dog.)
No paediatric oncologist has ever been told 'I can always have another kid.'

My cat got three x-rays and the total was $160. We have no pet health insurance so the amount was what it actually cost. I need one x-ray because the doctor says I probably need a hip replacement. The cost of my x-ray will be around $1,000. I wonder if my vet will do the x-ray for me?
If I could have a veterinarian for my primary health care provider, I'd be a lot healthier and more financially secure.

The legislature in Georgia is cowardly, isn't it? If guns everywhere is such a great idea, why are they afraid to have them in the halls of their capitol building? Why not let the visitors to their offices come in armed.?

Near Natick for me on the A of the same crossing Deb mentioned. I was going to try the vowels in order, but only got to the A before the successful completion notice popped up. I'd never heard either name. If I solved on paper, I'd still be wondering. In the olden days, when the Dead Sea was only sick, I'd have to wait for tomorrow's paper to check my answer.

I started solving the NYT puzzles through a subscription to the Seattle Post Intelligencer, which eventually merged with the Seattle Times. I remember those newlywed college days fondly. It doesn't seem it could have been over 40 years ago already.

WVC, Old Top! You have seemingly employed the well known Eagle Eye by identifying Johns avatar, one of your fellow Canadian native sons, on this Hump Day Wednesday!

Howie TBOQ 11:15 CST

Noooooooo! It can't be! Those are freedom fighters!
My government told me so and my government always fights for the truth and for those who are oppressed!
We need to help them against Assad- just like McCain, Obama, Kerry and Samantha Powers want! And just like they really want to help Ukraine!

Russia has good reason to support any government struggling against moslem terrorists.  Remember how Chechen moslem terrorists murdered 350 school children in Beslan.   Russia's terrorist semi autonomous republics have growing populations as Russia's population continues to decline.  The US, NATO and Russia all have a common interest in suppressing the world's terrorist populations.  We should not be agitating against Russia but support it as we did in the days after the self-imposed disintegration of the USSR.

The CIA has been telling for ten or twelve years that they have decimated El Qaeda but now they are telling us that El Qaeda is a growing threat in Syria, although they were not there before the CIA ratcheted up the war two years ago and had to be restrained from having the Navy fire cruise missiles into Syria.

We are really in trouble if the CIA's ineffectiveness in fighting "terrorism" during the last decade is any guide to the CIA's and Pentagon's new words telling us that El Qaeda is now alive and well not only in Afghanistan and Pakistan but in Syria as well. There must be better ways to deal with terrorists than spending hundreds of military lives, billions in resources, and a dozen year's time only to find more of them in more places still constituting a threat to our lives and wellbeing. How about trying more talk and diplomacy and less military waste?

The lack of action on the part of the US and West as well as Mr. Putin's support for Bashar el-Assad has resulted in the war in Syria now entering its fourth year.
The "moderate" opposition forces received no support, allowing the radaical Islamists and Jihadists to pour in. Mr. Assad had the support of Hezbollah.
There is absolutely no reason that Syria will not be the next Afghanistan. The only way to prevent that would be for the West to work with Mr. Putin to bolster Mr. Assad and from time to time it seems that the West would prefer Mr. Assad. The wholesale murder of your own people is apparently in the West not as serious as an al-Qaeda threat. But then the West and Mr. Putin are not going to work together.
Sometimes not getting involved is a policy and has a logic. Sometimes it leads to a much worse situation.
The West is in a lose-lose situation.
And it gets worse: the joker in the pack of cards is Israel. Israel will not allow Hezbollah, Mr. Assad or the Syrian opposition in any form or fashion to take their fight across the border or to take steps which would facilitate this.
If the West did not want limited military intervention three years ago, they may get an extensive regional war.
Sometimes red lines should not be imaginary.

That's why in the homeland I often like to pretend that I'm Swiss-American.
-(which I am in part) and If you are 'Swiss' the changes to be a 'communist' are much lower - as if you are partly from any other European country - They are all 'tax collecting communists' and real (rich) Americans want to roam tax free...
The question -
Why don't they move to
Ita-
ly?

(see follow-up comment at the Euro lecture thread)

What is the price of a less than living wage?
Workers are demeaned by the government support they require for livable housing, healthcare and food.
Taxes one federal deficits are required to pay that government support. The Walmart's and McDonald's are subsidized by the tax payers. There are less wages available to strengthen our economy through purchases of goods and services.

The only group that could possibly want this are the stockholders and executives, but even they are at risk. Over $1.7 trillion that has been diverted from workers to profits is sitting unused and unspent in corporate coffers with many corporations finding nothing better to do than buy back their own stock.

We have record high profits and record low payrolls as a percentage of GDP. This increasing inequality will bury all of us if not reversed through federal intervention. The minimum wage and immigration reform are good places to start.

Nice analysis, Dan.  The only thing I might disagree with you is that we should provide the Ukrainians cover so that they can concentrate on nation-building instead of cowering at Russian intimidation.

With respect to Russia, President Obama is like a chess player whose opponent has made a relatively small but palpable blunder. The worst thing a player in such a position can do is react too fast or over-confidently. The right tactic is to build on the blunder and gradually increase its weight on the opponent.

After all, this crisis began when the Ukrainian people dared to defy a police state that was in Putin's pocket and would never, ever have allowed European-style reforms beyond the cosmetic. Now, owing to Putin's aggression, the rest of Ukraine understands exactly what the stakes are, and hopefully will realize that unity and shared sacrifice are the only way to protect their independence from Russia. Ukraine cannot, of course, formally acquiesce in Crimea's loss. But Crimean irredentism would be the biggest mistake Ukraine could make now. Far better for them to put that issue on the back burner and concentrate on reconstruction . . . which Putin is going to make as difficult as he can. That's where the West can play a role. We've proved many times over that we can't "nation-build." But maybe the Ukrainians, without our generous assistance, can do it themselves.

There is the awkward historical difficulty of 10 million Ukrainians killed by Stalin for resisting collectivization. There are so many Russians in Ukraine today because they were encouraged to replace the labor of 10 million dead peasants. This and much more abuse at the hands of the Russians creates a different situation than in Finland.

A Russian leader who aspires to restore Soviet power has to be a frightening prospect to Ukrainians.
